ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Sometimes the class discussions were diverted by Professor Ashton, so it was hard to stay on topic. The course structure, and key takeaways from each class, were sometimes unclear, especially during the first half.

I very much enjoyed the format of the course, though it heavily relied on the diligence and verbosity of the attending students. When discussions heated up, the class proved great stage for some of the more thoughtful discourse I've been apart of at FES. At other times, for one reason or another, the class dragged a bit. I thought the number of field trips to be appropriate, learning quite a bit on each one. I believe the order could be adjusted a bit, maybe with the taxonomy lessons moved up earlier in the course. Lastly, a quick mention about the guest speakers. I know it's hard to have guests craft a custom deck for where we are in the curriculum, but we might find more meaningful interaction with a roundtable discussion with our guests, rather than the powerpoint presentation of organization intros and high level slides.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Most of the assigned readings were great and really interested. We loved the guest speakers.
We had great speakers and the conversations were provocative
The course material is very important for forest managers.
aluded to it above, but the best part was when discussion became lively. Fun to have Mark and Mary and Talbott weighing in with different opinions...that didn't always line up!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Structure --I think we should start with an overview of entomology and current forest health issues, and then work our way into the literature analysis. Students need a foundation before moving forward into critical discussion.
It needs to be organized better

Field trips need to be more concise and more closely tied to course material. Student group projects should be done in depth on a topic. A more cohesive syllabus is needed to situate this course among the other forest health disciplines (i.e. this course covers insects/pathogens, acid deposition, etc. and not invasive plants). Three teachers was a bit excessive since most of the course was student-based discussion. The system, so fondly practiced at F&ES, of reading scientific papers and then awkwardly discussing them for 3 hours can be a waste of time. Instead, reading papers before class, then conducting a field trip or lab or something applied would be much better.
aligning subject material of the guest speakers...

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes
The field trips were helpful but sometimes way to long and/or not specifically related.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is a very importatn topic and should be taught every year

I thought this course offered a nice synthesis of prior courses and disciplines, while at the same time introducing a subject matter new to most of the students. I enjoyed having this course in my final semester at school...perhaps might have been a bit lost if it were in my first year?

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fulfills a curriculum requirement and the material was of interest to me. Plus, I like and respect all of the instructors, and thought the small seminar format would be challenging.
I am interested in gaining a better understanding of forest pests and pathogens

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Somewhat. I wish I had gained more in the basic entomology/diagnostic realm.
yes
barely.
Certainly so. I realize there's a lot to cover on the subject of Forest Health, so criticisms around scope / depth have some merit, but there's not a better way to get exposure to everything.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Good course if you are interested in gaining an understanding of the impact of pests, pathogens,climate change and invasives on the health of forest systems
Speak with the professors first so you know what you're getting into.
